Award.AbstractNarration:
Algebraic topology arose out of development of algebraic methods to answer concrete questions about geometric shapes. One of the most successful tools originally developed is homology theory, which gives qualitative information about shapes that remains unchanged if the shapes are moved, twisted, or stretched. Several decades were dedicated to understanding homology and producing a sequence of new, more general tools that shared similar properties but detected different types of information. Many new and powerful tools were developed; in addition, a surprising connection was discovered with number theory. This research focuses on expanding on our understanding of this connection by lifting recent developments from number theory to topology, and applying this new machinery of algebraic topology to concrete problems about geometric shapes such as knots and links.

This research project extends work of the investigator and collaborators in constructing structured ring spectra realizing connections to specific moduli of abelian varieties. These phenomena and their impact on the chromatic filtration in stable homotopy theory have been examined up through chromatic height two. The project aims to produce new information at chromatic height three through the study of Picard modular surfaces and to apply these results to detecting higher periodic phenomena in the stable homotopy category. Further, the project will study positivity phenomena in the theories of modular and automorphic forms and their connection to the additive locus in chromatic homotopy theory. The work also aims to extend recent results in constructing Khovanov spectra associated to knots and to show Khovanov's work on complexes associated to tangles lifts to a theory of stable homotopy types associated to tangles. Finally, the project will apply work in stable equivariant homotopy theory, in particular the equivariant Tate diagonal, to realize homology-level constructions in Heegaard-Floer homology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Homotopy theory was originally developed to help understand qualitative properties of shapes, from basic ones in everyday life to large-scale features of shapes like the universe we live in, based on how they are built from elementary pieces. The subject has been applied to a wide variety of areas, including mathematical physics to geometry. Deeper investigations in this area  led to surprising patterns and an unexpected connection to a purely algebraic subject, called the theory of formal group laws, that is usually a part of the study of number theory. These connections largely fall under the header of chromatic homotopy theory. Chromatic theory aims to determine exactly how strong these connections are: what objects and structures connected to formal group law theory, and other algebraic areas, can be represented by structures in geometry.


Our particular focus is on the study of so-called structured rings: objects in homotopy theory that share features with pure algebra and with geometry, that record not just algebraic equations but also structure that remembers why these identities are true. From some perspectives, structured rings behave very similarly to numbers we are familiar with from ordinary life: they have analogues of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. From other perspectives, they are quite different: they have new operations with no ordinary, often occuring in overdetermined situations where an equation is true for multiple reasons. Again, we often would like do determine exactly how strong these connections are: what objects and structures in ordinary arithmetic are also present for structured rings.

Over the course of this research we have developed both some positive and negative results in these directions. Of particular note has been a problem in the intersection of these: an object with strong connections to formal group theory that it was hoped had a representative as a structured ring. Our work found new, unexpected types of overdetermined operations that showed that this was impossible, solving a 40-year-old problem in the field.
